job_title: Patient Acess Representative in Chestertown, MD
Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Chestertown, MD
pros: close to home, thats about it
cons: poor pay. staff to patient ratio

pros: a good steady job that you can work as much as you want

review_title: Overall a pleasant but not overly-rewarding experience.
pros: It is small enough that you don't get overly lost in the system. There are health benefits available to part-time employees as well as full-time employees. There are discounts for the insurance premiums for visiting with a wellness person to assess your health status and to help you to figure out how to improve your health.
cons: There could be more emphasis on providing timely feedback for employeee performance. There were very small performance incentives (ie raises) available. Employee health was housed away from the main hospital and it could be inconvenient to have to drive 25 minutes to get to the other hospital to visit with employee health.

pros: Small hospital setting conducive to establishing relationships with co-workers and patients.  Salary comparable to large urban areas.
cons: Lack of management accountability.  Management resistant to process improvement via employee observations/suggestions.  Experience is rarely valued over tenured employees. Evaluations aren't timely, sometimes not done at all.

pros:
Excellent Benefits!  You have great medical insurance coverage with low copays if you stay within the Shore medical group. 
The time off, vacation, and sick time is rolled into one and is very generous. It increases every five years or so until you reach 9 hours every pay period.  If you are not a nurse or an employee who Has to be there to interact directly with patients then your work hours can be flexible.
cons:
Beware of this employers!  This is a very hateful and catty place to work. I know all companies have their issues with hateful employees but I have never worked somewhere with this much lying and animosity toward each other. And management and human resources department is just as bad. They don't want to deal with any type of conflict or issue so things formally reported go unaddressed.   Since this town is so small management has hired family members, people they go to church with, ect., with no skills for the job they are supposed to be doing and the managers cover for them.  No wonder this hospital is so poor that it may shut down.
It really gets to you after a while and you become sad and hate going to work.  I know this sounds petty but I am telling you will have a knife in your back each and every day.  
The pay is terrible!  They will start you out between 8.00 and 14.00 dollars and your only increase will be 2%. That increase has been in place for years as they cry about how poor the company is while the executive level has very high salaries. They talk constantly about how we all need to tighten our belts and be thankful we have a job while they live in luxury. If you end up working ther I am sure you will understand what I am talking about.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Easton, MD
pros: The wages are fair compared to area hospitls. Opportunity to perform and  use skills such as intubation and NICU
cons: Since the end of 2017  longtime respiratory management has retired and changes have been made. No changes have been positive and do not benefit the patients

pros: People I worked with were hard working, low paid individuals who really cared about what they do. One blonde female senior manager who has a lot of power is just cruel to her staff.
cons: One senior manager who has been given lots of power is just cruel to those that work under her. When I complained to HR I was told that she has a “different” management style. Yeah one based on belittling those under her.

pros: The other employees were great to work with.  Salaries were not bad.
cons: Short lunch breaks and not much room for personal growth.

pros: The doctors are fantastic! They are very willing to explain things.
cons: A lot of random tasks to complete.
